tweets.content: @TI_EU: Redflags.eu is a tool to monitor, check & flag #corruption risks in public procurement - Gabriela Nagy of @Transparency_HU #IODC16pic.twitter.com/sSoiSEWzly
@smartdublin: Discussing the use of open data in public procurement to increase transparency & efficiency #IODC16 @dublinkedpic.twitter.com/u9omYZ9FLn
@OpenAidGermany: How can public procurement can become more transparent + accountable @nrginstitute @opencontracting #iodc16pic.twitter.com/VkUuGXoc5u
@opengovpart: .@RaduPuchiu discussing how #opendata was used to fight corruption in public procurement in the health sector in Romania #IODC16pic.twitter.com/xAxJnpc7gZ
@Fscrollini: Now @Prozorro from Ukraine tells us the story of the Ukraine public procurement in Ukraine #IODC16

info: This session brought together a geographically balanced group of leaders on the open contracting domain from government and civil society with the objective of looking at the question of how open data can be used to achieve really strong outcomes in terms of transparency, accountability and efficiency.

session.description: The session will to present concrete examples for how open data has been used to make public procurement processes more transparent, accountable, and effective to promote positive changes in government and people’s lives. The session will seek to reveal how open data can help to clean up public procurements,...Read more

conference_notes:
• Ana Zúñiga (Government México City): “Mexico City is the first place in the world to open its procurement with the Open Contracting Data standard. The process was done with the collaboration of civil society and not by the government means alone. As a result: the city is now having new bidders and working to attract new visitors to the website”.
  • Michael Canares (World Wide Web Foundation's Open Data Lab Jakarta): “Open data is not an only child, and definitely there is a need to work along with other dynamics for real change”.
  • Lindsey Marchessault (Open Contracting Partnership): “Open contracting has to be taken very seriously because at the end of the day the tangible results of procurement are hospitals, schools, medicines”.
  • Gabriella Nagy (Transparency International Hungary): “Open data should not be an end but a means to support change”.
  • Romain Tales (Etalab. Government of France): “In France the change for open procurement started with the legal aspects, that is, with a modification of the French code for public procurement”.
  • Hera Hussain (Open Corporates): “Procurement is the honey pot for corruption, so it is at the heart of fighting corruption”.
name: Open Data and Public Procurement
